posts.name: Jason VanderMolen
posts.cooked: My team is looking into purchasing an updated PDP , but we are confused on which one we should settle with. We have ran the PDP 1 for a handful of years, but since we started using swerve, we’ve ran into issues with not having enough large power ports for the rest of our motors. I looked at the CTR page and saw that there is a PDP 2.0, but there doesn’t seem to be any CAN ports. I also looked at the REV PDH and have heard a few teams have issues with using it. Do we just stick to using the PDP 1 or go with a new PDP ?

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
I’ve heard a few folks had issues with the PDH ’s controllable breaker channel or the voltage display, but nothing else comes to mind. Ours have been solid.

Personally, I’m averse to running year one products from any vendor in a critical application when I can avoid it.  It’s so common to get burned by either a supply chain issue, an early-production quality issue, or just some quirk we don’t have the bandwidth to characterize and understand.

But CTRE has been on a winning streak lately, and it’s easy to terminate a CAN bus with your own resistor if you want to go that route.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
While it’s true there have been a few reports of issues with the rev PDH , as a whole it works very well and I would wager 99% of robots ran it last year. I did not encounter a single robot running the PDP 1 last year including 148 who was previously the most notable hold out running a PDP 1 with swerve in '22.

PDP 2 just came out this fall so it is an unknown, there are some potential advantages and disadvantages. Can’t speak to the construction or internals yet without having one, but CTRE is usually solid there

Being able to have connectors exit on only 2 sides can be nice for packaging.

No dedicated location for rio or radio / peripherals, rules for how this will work are unknown, but these will likely require 2 of these outputs.

Assuming the above, 22 40A motors allowed compared to 20 on the PDH , there’s also some lower current ports you can use for motors with the PDH (switchable ones).

No CAN on PDH means you’ll need to rely on your own logging vs DS logs to see motor current, this will make CSAs less able to help you if you don’t do logging well.

Requires you to terminate the bus separately from the PDH

PDP 2 is $45 cheaper

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: I would say that if they have to answer this question, they should go with the Rev PDP .  Having the data readily available to FTAs in the dashboard is incredibly helpful.  Teams going with CTRE ’s PDP 2 will have to find another way to single-source that data for troubleshooting, and I suspect it is more targetted toward teams that already don’t use the dashboard for their data.

posts.name: Jason VanderMolen
posts.cooked: So they rev pdh would be the best route for a new pdp? We had one come with the game kit and middle of week 1 it had broke and wouldn’t distribute power, and the rev fuses usually tore out the terminals when we had to remove them.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked:
Billfred:

I’ve heard a few folks had issues with the PDH ’s controllable breaker channel or the voltage display, but nothing else comes to mind. Ours have been solid.

It’s worth noting that neither of these features directly impacts the device’s performance or primary usage.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
The rev breakers require special care to remove, and even then the housings can pop off.  But they have substantially better performance than the old snap-actions so it’s worth it from that point of view.  After all - how often do you remove them?  I don’t think we removed a single one last year.

In terms of durability, Mike covered it.  The majority of teams use the PDH without a problem.  It’s been a good product for us.  And it’s tie-in with the dashboard is invaluable for many teams.

Mike_Schreiber:

I did not encounter a single robot running the PDP 1 last year

The only example I can think of is 3534 House of Cards, who ran it because of some issue they heard relating to current if I remember correctly.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked: I’d recommend you reach out to Rev Support ( support@revrobotics.com ) on this. It should not be possible to cause the PDH to not distribute power as long as there is a good breaker in it. They may want to get this unit back / replace it if it is not functional.

posts.name: Jason VanderMolen
posts.cooked: Okay, i will talk to my team later today about purchasing the rev pdh. Thank you everyone who answered my questions. You have been very helpful.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
J_VMOLEN:

it had broke and wouldn’t distribute power

Mike_Schreiber:

It should not be possible to cause the PDH to not distribute power as long as there is a good breaker in it.

If you crack the main PCB (I haven’t done a teardown of one yet so idk if its the same as a CTRE PDP ), but I have done this once after some hard impacts or a drop. Dan K helped me diagnose it in the pit, but it was tough as nails to find. If we hit the skid plate really hard right below the PDP the crack would disconnect temporarily and force the bot to reboot.

We swapped it with a spare from pit admin and then took it apart completely to inspect it. Big big crack across several traces.

Thinking back on this was probably during 2016 as we were the 'defense clearer ’ jumping the moat, high beam, etc and slamming back to the ground multiple times a match. We broke lots of parts that year.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Mike_Schreiber:

While it’s true there have been a few reports of issues with the rev PDH , as a whole it works very well and I would wager 99% of robots ran it last year.

CSA here, that’s definitely a big overestimation (though perhaps it’s true at your events). I see quite a few teams that re-use the PDP from their rookie kit every year (or the 2015 kit if the team is older than that); in fact, it’s common enough for that to be one of the things I look for first when helping investigate mysterious reboots now, as the mini fuses required for the RIO and radio tend to be worn out and loose on the older PDPs that have been used year after year.

I don’t think PDH usage is anywhere above 80% in my district, and I would guess it’s closer to 70%. That said, it is my preferred panel to work with. I’ve only seen one PDH -related failure actually give a team a power problem during a match, and that was from under-stripped 6 AWG main power wires making poor contact, heating up, and melting everything around it inside until the connection broke. I’ve seen loose screw connections to the PDP more often, which causes its own problems.

posts.name: Nathan Julian
posts.cooked: I had the wrong CD thread open

Mike_Schreiber:

I did not encounter a single robot running the PDP 1 last year

2056 used one last season

Team 2056 OP Robotics - 2024 Technical Binder Release Technical Discussion

link_counts.title: Team 2056 OP Robotics - 2024 Technical Binder Release

posts.name: Nathan Julian
posts.cooked:
While I’m here though, we’ve used the PDH on our past few robots and it has been very reliable. Besides the fact that we got early units with a faulty voltmeter and having some confusion with the switchable port, everything has been good. I also much prefer the latching wago connectors on the PDH to the annoying ones on the PDP .

However, I do like the idea of screw terminals for the battery connection, I’ve heard of a failure or two from other teams’ PDHs where a poor connection there caused things to get melty. We just always make sure to give the battery wires a strong tug to test their connection.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
I was on the fence on this issue in earlier posts when the PDP2 was announced, however at this point, having put some thought into all the issues I’ve run into as a CSA …

… I’ve decided to put the PDP2 on my do not recommend list.

The single exception would be for teams that use advanced logging to an SD/USB stick and can have the motor amperage data available readily for troubleshooting. Even that is not quite a 100% replacement for some of the data on a PDP1 or PDH .

If that’s not your team (and that’s a vast majority from what I’ve seen) the lack of CAN bus and per-port load monitoring makes this device a non-starter for me.

Too many times, be it a battery issue, wiring issue, brown-out issue, or something else, I’ve looked at that data to assist a team with an issue. That’s not to say I’ve used it for every issue, but enough of them to say it will be missed. And I don’t want to recommend, or even be neutral about the product if it means I would be missing important data that could help a team.

Hence, I do not recommend the product for the vast majority of teams. Those that do use it I would consider advising them to do so at their own risk and with full knowledge of the limitations.

Now, between the PDP1 and PDH , I don’t have a strong opinion. Yes REV did have some issues with one batcho of PDH ’s, the voltage display was incorrect, and yes, the breakers themselves can be tricker to pull, but that is not a major differentiator for me. I have not experienced issues with the switched circuit, but am aware they did exist, in what quantity I can’t say.

I look at the PDP / PDH as the same way I look at PP45s and Wago connectors. If you can correctly strip and insert them fully and properly into a Wago, I believe the PDH has a slight edge. If your team struggled with correctly stripping and inserting wire into a Wago connector, you may have come training/learning to do to reliably wire your PDH as well.

I think the additional ports on the PDH over the PDP are an advantage to teams, especially those running swerve, and should be a factor in your decision.

Those points aside, both products are quality products and both vendors have supported them and I believe will continue to support them fully. I don’t think either of the PDP / PDH is a “wrong” choice.

posts.name: Galen Spooner
posts.cooked: I would wholeheartedly recommend the REV PDH . Having CAN connectivity with your power distribution is a game changer, and certainly helped us diagnose brownouts last season. Also, from my experience with both the CTRE PDP and REV PDH , the PDH ’s connectors are just so much easier to use without sacrificing strength. The extra high current ports are also super useful since you have swerve.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 2035 Captain, Software Lead, Driver, Design

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 2035 Captain, Software Lead, Driver, Design

posts.cooked: I would absolutely recommend the REV PDH . The WAGO connectors are so much easier to use than the CTRE connectors. In addition, we have had numerous issues with the low-amperage connectors used for powering the RoboRIO on the CTRE PDP , costing us multiple matches. We have had no such issues with the REV PDH , however, which has been a game-changer for us this season.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: Hi newish team here I have question we are looking to build and field a tank drive robot andy mark long chassis and we have lots of old electronics such as the ctre pdp would it better to keep it and use it or buy and field either the pdp 2 or pdh we all have no experience all new members, mentors, and teacher.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
If I had a CTRE PDP and a REV PDH in-hand, I’d probably use the PDH as it has some quality of life improvements.

If I only had a PDP in-hand, I’d want to know about my budget.  If I’ve got $5k to burn on the robot, sure no biggie.  If I had $1k, I might kick the can down the road.
